conclusion: Use the ideal gas law to relate pressure, volume, and temperature.
Internal energy U of the gas is related to temperature T by U = aT.
Temperature at state A is T0, with pressure p0 and volume V0.
State C has pressure 0.6p0 and volume 0.5V0.
Determine temperature at state A using ideal gas law: TA = T0.
Determine temperature at state C: TC = 0.3T0.
Temperature at state B varies linearly between states A and C.
Coordinates of A are (p0, V0) and C are (0.6p0, 0.5V0).
Calculate slope of line connecting A and C: m = 5V0/4p0.
Equation of line is V = (5V0/4p0)p - V0/4.
Find V at state B when p = 0.6p0: VB = V0.
